elements.desc:
The `iron-ajax` element exposes network request functionality.

    <iron-ajax
        auto
        url="http://gdata.youtube.com/feeds/api/videos/"
        params='{"alt":"json", "q":"chrome"}'
        handle-as="json"
        on-response="handleResponse"
        debounce-duration="300"></iron-ajax>

With `auto` set to `true`, the element performs a request whenever
its `url`, `params` or `body` properties are changed. Automatically generated
requests will be debounced in the case that multiple attributes are changed
sequentially.

Note: The `params` attribute must be double quoted JSON.

You can trigger a request explicitly by calling `generateRequest` on the
element.

events.desc: Fired when an error is received.

jsdoc.description: Fired when an error is received.
jsdoc.orig:
*
     * Fired when an error is received.
     *
     * @event error

events.name: error

events.desc: Fired when a request is sent.

jsdoc.description: Fired when a request is sent.
jsdoc.orig:
*
     * Fired when a request is sent.
     *
     * @event request

events.name: request

events.desc: Fired when a response is received.

jsdoc.description: Fired when a response is received.
jsdoc.orig:
*
     * Fired when a response is received.
     *
     * @event response

events.name: response

properties.name: activeRequests
properties.desc:
An Array of all in-flight requests originating from this iron-ajax
element.

properties.name: auto
properties.desc:
If true, automatically performs an Ajax request when either `url` or
`params` changes.

properties.name: body
properties.desc:
Body content to send with the request, typically used with "POST"
requests.

If body is a string it will be sent unmodified.

If Content-Type is set to a value listed below, then
the body will be encoded accordingly.

   * `content-type="application/json"`
     * body is encoded like `{"foo":"bar baz","x":1}`
   * `content-type="application/x-www-form-urlencoded"`
     * body is encoded like `foo=bar+baz&x=1`

Otherwise the body will be passed to the browser unmodified, and it
will handle any encoding (e.g. for FormData, Blob, ArrayBuffer).

properties.name: contentType
properties.desc:
Content type to use when sending data. If the `contentType` property
is set and a `Content-Type` header is specified in the `headers`
property, the `headers` property value will take precedence.

properties.name: debounceDuration
properties.desc: Length of time in milliseconds to debounce multiple requests.

properties.name: generateRequest
properties.desc: Performs an AJAX request to the specified URL.

properties.name: handleAs
properties.desc:
Specifies what data to store in the `response` property, and
to deliver as `event.detail.response` in `response` events.

One of:

   `text`: uses `XHR.responseText`.

   `xml`: uses `XHR.responseXML`.

   `json`: uses `XHR.responseText` parsed as JSON.

   `arraybuffer`: uses `XHR.response`.

   `blob`: uses `XHR.response`.

   `document`: uses `XHR.response`.

properties.name: headers
properties.desc:
HTTP request headers to send.

Example:

    <iron-ajax
        auto
        url="http://somesite.com"
        headers='{"X-Requested-With": "XMLHttpRequest"}'
        handle-as="json"></iron-ajax>

Note: setting a `Content-Type` header here will override the value
specified by the `contentType` property of this element.

properties.name: lastError
properties.desc: lastRequest's error, if any.

properties.name: lastRequest
properties.desc: The most recent request made by this iron-ajax element.

properties.name: lastResponse
properties.desc:
lastRequest's response.

Note that lastResponse and lastError are set when lastRequest finishes,
so if loading is true, then lastResponse and lastError will correspond
to the result of the previous request.

The type of the response is determined by the value of `handleAs` at
the time that the request was generated.

properties.name: loading
properties.desc: True while lastRequest is in flight.

properties.name: method
properties.desc:
The HTTP method to use such as 'GET', 'POST', 'PUT', or 'DELETE'.
Default is 'GET'.

properties.name: params
properties.desc:
An object that contains query parameters to be appended to the
specified `url` when generating a request. If you wish to set the body
content when making a POST request, you should use the `body` property
instead.

properties.name: queryString
properties.desc:
The query string that should be appended to the `url`, serialized from
the current value of `params`.

properties.name: requestHeaders
properties.desc:
An object that maps header names to header values, first applying the
the value of `Content-Type` and then overlaying the headers specified
in the `headers` property.

properties.name: requestUrl
properties.desc:
The `url` with query string (if `params` are specified), suitable for
providing to an `iron-request` instance.

properties.name: sync
properties.desc:
Toggle whether XHR is synchronous or asynchronous. Don't change this
to true unless You Know What You Are Doing™.

properties.name: timeout
properties.desc: Set the timeout flag on the request.

properties.name: toRequestOptions
properties.desc:
Request options suitable for generating an `iron-request` instance based
on the current state of the `iron-ajax` instance's properties.

return.type: {url: string, method: (string|undefined), async: (boolean|undefined), body: (ArrayBuffer|ArrayBufferView|Blob|Document|FormData|null|string|undefined|Object), headers: (Object|undefined), handleAs: (string|undefined), withCredentials: (boolean|undefined)}

properties.name: url
properties.desc: The URL target of the request.

properties.name: verbose
properties.desc: If true, error messages will automatically be logged to the console.

properties.name: withCredentials
properties.desc: Set the withCredentials flag on the request.

properties.name: hostAttributes
properties.desc: Fired when an error is received.

right.value: contentType, body, sync, handleAs, withCredentials, timeout, auto)
right.raw: 'contentType, body, sync, handleAs, withCredentials, timeout, auto)'

elements.desc:
iron-request can be used to perform XMLHttpRequests.

    <iron-request id="xhr"></iron-request>
    ...
    this.$.xhr.send({url: url, params: params});

properties.name: abort
properties.desc: Aborts the request.

properties.name: aborted
properties.desc: Aborted will be true if an abort of the request is attempted.

properties.name: completes
properties.desc:
A promise that resolves when the `xhr` response comes back, or rejects
if there is an error before the `xhr` completes.

properties.name: errored
properties.desc:
Errored will be true if the browser fired an error event from the
XHR object (mainly network errors).

properties.name: parseResponse
properties.desc:
Attempts to parse the response body of the XHR. If parsing succeeds,
the value returned will be deserialized based on the `responseType`
set on the XHR.

return.desc:
The parsed response,
or undefined if there was an empty response or parsing failed.

properties.name: progress
properties.desc:
An object that contains progress information emitted by the XHR if
available.

properties.name: response
properties.desc:
A reference to the parsed response body, if the `xhr` has completely
resolved.

properties.name: send
properties.desc: Sends an HTTP request to the server and returns the XHR object.

params.name: options
params.type: {url: string, method: (string|undefined), async: (boolean|undefined), body: (ArrayBuffer|ArrayBufferView|Blob|Document|FormData|null|string|undefined|Object), headers: (Object|undefined), handleAs: (string|undefined), withCredentials: (boolean|undefined)}
params.desc:
url The url to which the request is sent.
    method The HTTP method to use, default is GET.
    async By default, all requests are sent asynchronously. To send synchronous requests,
        set to true.
    body The content for the request body for POST method.
    headers HTTP request headers.
    handleAs The response type. Default is 'text'.
    withCredentials Whether or not to send credentials on the request. Default is false.
  timeout: (Number|undefined)

properties.name: status
properties.desc: A reference to the status code, if the `xhr` has completely resolved.

properties.name: statusText
properties.desc: A reference to the status text, if the `xhr` has completely resolved.

properties.name: succeeded
properties.desc:
Succeeded is true if the request succeeded. The request succeeded if it
loaded without error, wasn't aborted, and the status code is ≥ 200, and
< 300, or if the status code is 0.

The status code 0 is accepted as a success because some schemes - e.g.
file:// - don't provide status codes.

properties.name: timedOut
properties.desc: TimedOut will be true if the XHR threw a timeout event.

properties.name: xhr
properties.desc:
A reference to the XMLHttpRequest instance used to generate the
network request.

properties.name: _encodeBodyObject

params.name: body
params.desc: The given body of the request to try and encode.

params.name: contentType
params.desc:
The given content type, to infer an encoding
    from.

return.desc:
Either the encoded body as a string, if successful,
    or the unaltered body object if no encoding could be inferred.

properties.name: _updateStatus
properties.desc: Updates the status code and status text.

properties.name: _wwwFormUrlEncode

params.name: object
params.desc: The object to encode as x-www-form-urlencoded.

properties.name: _wwwFormUrlEncodePiece

params.name: str
params.desc: A key or value to encode as x-www-form-urlencoded.

iron-ajax.desc:
The `iron-ajax` element exposes network request functionality.

    <iron-ajax
        auto
        url="http://gdata.youtube.com/feeds/api/videos/"
        params='{"alt":"json", "q":"chrome"}'
        handle-as="json"
        on-response="handleResponse"
        debounce-duration="300"></iron-ajax>

With `auto` set to `true`, the element performs a request whenever
its `url`, `params` or `body` properties are changed. Automatically generated
requests will be debounced in the case that multiple attributes are changed
sequentially.

Note: The `params` attribute must be double quoted JSON.

You can trigger a request explicitly by calling `generateRequest` on the
element.

     * Fired when an error is received.

     * @event response

An object that contains query parameters to be appended to the

iron-request.desc:
iron-request can be used to perform XMLHttpRequests.

    <iron-request id="xhr"></iron-request>
    ...
    this.$.xhr.send({url: url, params: params});

properties.desc: Aborts the request.

properties.name: aborted
properties.desc: Aborted will be true if an abort of the request is attempted.

properties.name: completes
properties.desc:
A promise that resolves when the `xhr` response comes back, or rejects
if there is an error before the `xhr` completes.

properties.name: errored
properties.desc:
Errored will be true if the browser fired an error event from the
XHR object (mainly network errors).

properties.name: parseResponse
properties.desc:
Attempts to parse the response body of the XHR. If parsing succeeds,

return.desc:
The parsed response,
